title: 110_s1268
content: The Act titled "Domestic Offshore Energy Security Act" focuses on the development and inventory of certain outer continental shelf resources. The "United States Person" definition includes citizens, lawful residents, and entities majority-owned by individuals described in paragraph (1). They are authorized to engage in activities involving hydrocarbon resources in foreign exclusive economic zones. The United States Person definition allows citizens, lawful residents, and majority-owned entities to engage in hydrocarbon exploration and extraction activities in foreign exclusive economic zones, including those contiguous to the US. The Secretary of the Treasury is authorized to approve travel-related transactions for such activities in Cuba. Federal Regulations allow travel to, from, or within Cuba for exploration and extraction of hydrocarbon resources in foreign maritime Exclusive Economic Zones contiguous to the US. Authorized persons include employees, executives, agents, and consultants of oil and gas companies. Additionally, there is a moratorium on oil and gas leasing in certain areas of the Gulf of Mexico, with changes to the Gulf of Mexico Energy Security Act of 2006. The Secretary of the Interior will establish regulations for environmental safeguards in oil and gas exploration on the outer Continental Shelf, including surety bond requirements for incident mitigation. The Secretary of the Interior will establish regulations for environmental safeguards in oil and gas exploration on the outer Continental Shelf, including provisions for liability in case of damage or loss, adherence to Spill Prevention regulations, and ensuring facilities are not visible from coastal shores. The Secretary of the Interior will establish regulations for environmental safeguards in oil and gas exploration on the outer Continental Shelf, including provisions to mitigate the impact on coastal vistas, ensure no significant adverse effects on fish or wildlife, and impose seasonal limitations to protect breeding and wildlife migration patterns. The Interior, Environment, and Related Agencies Appropriations Act, 2006 is amended to include leasing activities in additional areas. The Secretary of the Interior may conduct an inventory of oil and gas resources off the southeastern coast of the United States. The Secretary of the Interior may conduct an inventory of oil and gas resources off the southeastern coast of the United States, including the states of Virginia, North Carolina, South Carolina, or Georgia. The inventory must use the best available technology for accurate resource estimates and can only be conducted if requested by the Governor of the state. Reports on the inventory must be submitted to Congress and the requesting Governor, with necessary appropriations authorized for this purpose. The Energy Policy Act of 2005 is amended to include enhanced oil recovery activities in geologically challenging fields.
